Award.AwardTitle: Nonlinear Couplings for Flows in Fractured Porous Media: Analysis and Numerical Algorithms
Award.AbstractNarration:
Recent changes in fracturing technologies have had a strong impact on the economic and political life, all over the world. In the United States, these technologies have increased the hydrocarbon reserves year-after-year by more than 15 percent. The oil and gas productions are substantially increased by creating new fractures that go deeply underground in different directions. Although this technology has been known for decades, many challenging problems had prevented it from being implemented. There is still a lack of fundamental knowledge about the long term impact of man-made fractures, not only on the environment in general, but also on basic human needs. Society needs robust, unbiased knowledge on the impacts of this technology, and our industry needs rigorous tools for predicting and controlling the geometrical and mechanical characteristics of the fractures underground. Algorithms and scientific tools that will be developed under this proposal can be used in many other areas of biochemical and biomedical research. The proposed research will be integrated within several educational programs, which include graduate and undergraduate courses. Junior and senior undergraduates, as well as graduate students, will participate in various stages of the proposed research. Associated industrial problems will stimulate engineering majors to learn fundamental mathematical topics, and will attract mathematics majors toward applied mathematics problems. Senior personnel will disseminate the results of this project, not only through professional meetings and journal publications, but also through a network of collaborations and partnerships with industry.

This proposal addresses fundamental issues related to modeling and computer simulation of strongly coupled systems in fractured reservoirs. The main challenges arise from the fact that the natural underground systems and substances that are utilized to produce fractures are subjected to coupled physical processes, such as stresses in solid rocks and flows of multiphase fluids in the multiscale system. This system is essentially a three-dimensional porous medium characterized by an extremely high ratio between the horizontal and vertical length of the fractures, and respectively, their width. In this investigation, main hydrodynamic features, observed in real life by reservoir engineers, will be modeled by using different sets of nonlinear partial differential equations in the porous regions and in the fractures. These systems of equations have not been studied before. The flow in the fractures does not follow the classical law (linear Darcy), and the inertial forces can no longer be neglected. Moreover, the dissipative effects due to the interaction between the fluid flows in the different regions must be taken into account. The proposal is focused on the combination of novel ideas in multigrid and domain decomposition algorithms, oriented to parallel architectures with the aim of achieving the best computational performance. In order to improve the retrieval of hydrocarbon resources, the proposal will also address the solution of optimization problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI and the Co-PIs supported by this award worked together as a team. While the proposed problems were generated by some fundamental needs of the reservoir fracturing industry, the team’s work has led to results of a much broader impact. The theoretical results and numerical models that were developed for the strongly coupled nonlinear problems in fractured porous media are impacting a very diverse community of scientists, not only those working in reservoir engineering.

 

The main discoveries address the modeling and mathematical analysis of multi-physics and multi-scale systems characterized by an extremely high ratio between the length and the width of the fractures (respectively, hundreds of meters, versus a few millimeters). We modeled essential hydrodynamic features for porous regions and fractures, by using different sets of nonlinear partial differential equations.

 

We showed that flow in the fractures is not subjected to Darcy’s law, but to highly non-linear PDEs, and the inertial forces can no longer be neglected.

 

We proved that traditional view on the fracture efficiency should be reconsidered, and the optimal length of the fracture is actually more than to 30% shorter than ones used for the current industrial models. We developed a new fundamental machinery - which can be easily implemented to optimize the design of the fracture in order to produce the same quantity of hydrocarbons, with a significantly lower impact on the environment.

 

Many of the team’s research results are already being used by engineers, towards improving the design of fractures in oil reservoirs.

 

Another significant industrial outcome generated by this project’s research is a free, open source software package – FEMUS which is available on GitHub: http://femttu.github.io/  FEMuS is an opensource Finite Element C++ library built on top of Petsc which allows scientists to build and solve multiphysics problems with multigrid and domain decomposition techniques. 

 

One of the broader impacts of the existing project relates to blood flows through arteries, in the presence of aneurysms, which is a bio-medical problem of crucial importance. The non-linear flows that were studied have turned out to be very appropriate for this field of biomedical research, and have been modeled by one of the Co-PIs (Aulisa) and his graduate students.

 

Some of the non-linear analysis techniques and tools that were developed in this project have been used towards modeling geometric flows such as the Willmore flow (a gradient flow of Willmore surfaces, which represent critical points of the bending energy from elasticity theory).

 

Another broader impact of this project is related to applying the team’s hydrodynamic models to Data mining, and to financial market analysis. The investigators found that the non-linear analysis models that were developed in this project are able to lead to a fully novel way of understanding Big Data, as well as predictions in the financial market behavior.

 

The scientific achievement corresponding to this funded award has resulted in more than 40 publications, and two books published by the CRC Press – Taylor and Francis Group. Financial support was used to support 5 students in their travels to more than 20 national and internationals meetings and conferences, where they disseminated the research results.

 

The team members have organized more than 8 mini-symposia, and special sections at SIAM, AIMS, and AMS international conferences. In addition, they have been invited to multiple conferences to disseminate their results.

 

The proposed research is integrated within several educational programs, which include new graduate and undergraduate courses, the Applied Mathematics Seminar, and general departmental colloquium series.

 

 

Students have participated in the various stages of this research, studying topics in the mathematical modeling and analysis of hydrodynamic processes.

 

Associated industrial, biomedical, and chemical research topics have also involved several graduate students from engineering and chemistry departments, who learned and used both of the basics and more advanced mathematical results obtained from this project to aid their research and develope applications.

 

Two of the PhD students in Mathematics who have been partly supported by this grant have already graduated and are now on tenure-track jobs. Two of the recently supported PhD students in Applied Mathematics are going to graduate in May 2018; they have obtained significant results on biomedical problems related to cardiovascular system modeling and each of them already received an NSF supported postdoctoral appointment offer at Florida State University starting in June 2018.

 

Three graduate students who worked on the project received several international, national, and state awards due to their achievements, including two best poster awards (SIAM CSE17 and Texas Applied Mathematics and Engineering Symposium 2017) and many travel awards.

 

70% of graduate students participating in this project consists of female students.

 

The PI and Co-PIs, as well as their graduate students, have disseminated their research findings through professional meetings and journal publications, as well as through a network of more than 7 collaborations and partnerships with industry.
